1. The key to successful weight loss is to develop healthy lifestyle habits based on diet and exercise. You may not like those words: diet and exercise. But you don\'t have to obsess over them either. Food just means eating healthy and with fewer calories.
Exercising means being more physically active.

2. Although people often focus on diet when trying to lose weight, staying active is also an essential component of a weight loss program. When you are active, your body uses energy (calories) to move, which helps burn the calories you take in from the food you eat.

3. Whatever activity you choose, do it regularly. Aim for at least 150 minutes of moderate physical activity per week or 75 minutes of vigorous aerobic activity per week, preferably spread throughout the week. Keep in mind that you may need more physical activity to lose weight and keep it off.
1. Eat a healthy breakfast: If you exercise in the morning, get up early enough to finish breakfast at least an hour before your workout.
2. Watch your food portion sizes: Be careful not to overdo it when it comes to how much you eat before exercise.
3. Snack well: Snacks eaten shortly before exercise probably won\'t give you extra energy if your workout lasts less than 60 minutes, but they can prevent distracting hunger pangs.
4. Eat after exercise: To help your muscles recover and replenish their glycogen stores, eat a meal containing carbohydrates and protein within two hours of your exercise session, if possible.
5. Drink: Don\'t forget to drink liquids. You need adequate fluids before, during and after exercise to help prevent dehydration.
BREAKFAST WITH OATS, FRUIT AND YOGURT
Fresh or frozen fruit to choose from
Topping of your choice such as peanut butter
In a large bowl, create a base of between 150-200 grams of natural Greek yogurt.
Add fruit, nuts to the yogurt, muesli or oatmeal base and finish the bowl with the chosen topping.
In a large bowl, create a base of between 150-200 grams of natural Greek yogurt.
Add fruit, nuts to the yogurt, muesli or oatmeal base and finish the bowl with the chosen topping.
Source of fiber Source of trace foods Source of vitamins
Calories: 110k Cal Protein: 2g Carbs: 26g Vitamin C: 67% of the Reference Daily Intake (RDI) Folate: 15% of the RDI Potassium: 10% of the RDI Magnesium: 6% of the RDI

Finish the bowl with the chosen topping such as cream of peanuts for example to give a touch of flavor to breakfast.
